bibl.title: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, July 27, 1890

div1.p: Lazear learns that he may observe surgical operations at St. Bartholomew's Hospital. He describes many sights in London.

div1.head: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, July 27, 1890

opener.dateline:
2 Queen's Square Place
London W.C.
Sunday July 27, 1890

div1.p:
After mailing a letter to
you yesterday afternoon, I went down
to St. Bartholomew's Hospital and learned
there that operations were held every
day and that I would be admitted to
the amphitheatre. They all admit foreign
medical students, and seem glad to have
them attend. I will now be able to
see operations every day of my stay here.
After leaving the hospital I took dinner
at a restaurant on the Strand. Afterward
I took a walk and near Charing Cross
I met Doctor Wilson and had a little
talk with him. He has been travelling
around on the continent and will
sail for home on August 7th. I went
to the “Savoy” and saw the “Gondoliers”.
It was played better than in New York but
the company might be improved, Geraldine
Ulmar is not in it now. The theatre is
small and is not to be compared with
our Casino. The theatres here are arranged
differently from in America. The orchestra
is divided into two and the back part of
it is called the pit. The highest prices are
charged for the front of the orchestra, then
comes the dress circle and then the pit.
I always go to the pit, you can see very
well from there, much better than from
the dress circle it seems to me. The only
disadvantage is that they do not reserve
the seats there and it is necessary to
go early. They usually charge half-a-crown
or sixty cents, A in some places only a
shilling. This morning I took a good
sleep which I was in need of and
got up too late for church. I am going
some place to-night, probably Westminster.
I took a walk this morning down about
St. James Park and saw \ Buckingham Palace
St. James Palace and Marlborough House, the
residence of the Prince of Wales, and then
along Pall Mall to Charing Cross where I
took lunch at one of Gatte's restaurants.
While I was there I saw Prof Martin
come in and I went up and spoke
to him. He is an Englishman, you remember.

On Sunday night I did not go to church
as I had intended but went to a band
concert in Hyde Park. The Sunday concert
is a new thing in London and I wanted
to see how it was taking with the people.
There was a great crowd there and many
of them seemed to appreciate the music.
However the appreciative class seemed to
be composed mostly of German and French,
the Britons as a rule came for a frolic.
On Monday I went to the Tower and
inspected it thoroughly, I suppose it is
the most historically interesting place
in the world. I got a few leaves
there which I send in this. The large
ivy leaf is from the Bloody Tower.
The small ivy leaf grew on a mound near
the Beauchamp Tower where all
those interesting carvings are found on
the wall. The yellow leaf grew on
a tree on Tower Green and it was
lying on the Va scaffold where Anne
Boleyn, etc were beheaded. Monday
night, I went to the Shaftsbury Theatre
and saw Willard play in “Judah”.
Yesterday I was at Guy's Hospital all
afternoon watching operations. In the
evening I went to the Criterian and
saw Charles Wyndows.

Norris came down from the Highlands
and took a room here yesterday.
I am going with him to the National
Gallery this morning. He will
return to America on the same
vessel with me.

I received your letter of the 17th yesterday
and enjoyed it very much. I will
attend to those Neuralgia Crystals. I hope
you found the weather more pleasant
in Brownsville than in Pittsburgh.
I received also a batch of papers, which
I have commenced to read.
